reasoning:
The critique targets a specific step in §3.3: that separately-aggregating bounded difference-making views become extremely fussy because even ~1 part in 10^22 of resources devoted to “bads” prevents a mostly-great future. This step supports (but is not necessary for) the broader “most plausible views are fussy / no easy eutopia” conclusion, since the essay also argues fussiness from unbounded linear views, from near-linearity of many bounded views, and from other fragility considerations. So centrality is modest.

The objection’s main move—engineering fault isolation—does not directly undermine the moral-aggregation claim being made. The essay’s point is not primarily about bads ‘propagating’ through a system, but about additive/separately-transformed aggregation: if disvalue from bads is scaled/treated such that a star-system’s worth of bads pushes you near the disvalue bound, then even perfectly sandboxed bads still count morally and still lower total value. Containment can matter by reducing intensity/duration (i.e., lowering bads per unit resource) or by making ‘bads’ rarer, but the critique doesn’t engage the core mathematical structure (separate concave transform on goods plus separate transform on bads) or show that realistic containment would change the scaling enough to defeat the 10^22-style conclusion under the specified view. Hence low strength.

Relevance is moderate: it engages Forethought’s Tier-2 modeling choice about how value aggregates and the implication that avoiding tiny fractions of bads requires near-perfectionist governance. It’s not directly a Tier-3 open question, but it does connect to live concerns about governance overreach and how “fragility” assumptions translate into institutional recommendations.
title: Fault isolation and sandboxing undermine the contaminant model of value
